comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Commissariat Store was built in c.1810, demolished in 1939. This is the north and east facades of the original U-shaped building (1810) which fronted on to Circular Quay so ships could unload directly into the warehouse. The rectangular 1812 building was behind fronting George Street. Detailed history (of foundation stone) - www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_01_2.cfm?itemid=4500322 Also - www.dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/commissariat_stores

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: @ State Records NSW - this seems to be a fairly rare picture of a very important and historic building just before it was unfortunately demolished.  There are a few on Picture Australia (including a Casneaux), but most of the Tyrrell Collection's many views of Circular Quay have a forest of ships' masts and funnels obscuring the building.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Yes it is a terrible shame that this wonderful building didn't survive the re-modelling of The Rocks. The demolition of such an historically significant building would never happen today.

comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content: real shame this building wasnt kept. it was tallest building in the colony at 60ft to ridge. some other photos of the building img849.imageshack.us/img849/9198/comstore1932.jpg img26.imageshack.us/img26/2527/comstore.jpg

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/35672655@N00] Thanks for adding these links, great to see the other side of the building facing the water.

comment._content: Wow, after years reading about it and never picturing it. It is a rare photo!
